campylobacter.name: Campylobacter
campylobacter.description: Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli are the main clinically relevant species of Campylobacter and are responsible for majority of human infections. Although C. jejuni is the most frequent cause of campylobacteriosis in humans, C. coli can contribute to 25% of the cases. Poultry and domestic animals are the principal reservoirs of infection, with the first being responsible directly and indirectly for 50%-80% of the reported human cases.
campylobacter.symptoms: Fever, severe abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhoea which can vary from slight to profuse and watery.
campylobacter.transmission: Ingestion of contaminated food. Main food sources are raw milk and raw or undercooked poultry. Spread to other foods by cross-contamination or contamination with untreated water.

salmonella.name: Salmonella
salmonella.description: There are more than 2200 different Salmonella serotypes and the great majority are capable of causing human infection. S. enteritidis and S. typhimurium are considered the most important serotypes from a public health perspective. Salmonella have typical animal reservoirs with many domestic species playing an important role as source of human infection, in particular hens, poultry, pigs and cattle.
salmonella.symptoms: Fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and diarrhoea.
salmonella.transmission: Humans become infected through the consumption of a wide variety of food derived from infected food animals (i.e. eggs, milk, meat and meat products). Food can also be contaminated by infected food-handlers or by cross contamination as a result of poor hygiene (bakery products, fruits, vegetables and water).

listeria.name: Listeria
listeria.description: L. monocytogenes is widely distributed in the environment; the bacterium may enter abattoirs with carrier animals but contamination of food products often originates from the environment in which these are processed rather than from animals. L. monocytogenes can cause abortion and stillborn in pregnant women and in infants and persons with a weakened immune system it may lead to septicaemia and meningitis.
listeria.symptoms: Influenza-like symptoms such as fever, headache and occasionally gastrointestinal symptoms. In pregnant women abortion and stillbirth. Meningoencephalitis in neonate and immunocompromised subjects.
listeria.transmission: The disease is most often associated with consumption of foods such as raw milk, soft cheese, meat-products, fish and fish products.

coli.name: Shigatoxin-producing Escherichia Coli (STEC)
coli.description: Shigatoxin-producing E. coli are zoonotic agents whose natural reservoirs are domestic ruminants (cattle, goats, sheep). Clinical course of STEC infection in humans may range from mild abdominal pain to haemorrhagic colitis and haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), a severe systemic condition characterised by anemia, thrombocytopenia and acute renal failure. HUS affects particularly small children.
coli.symptoms: Abdominal cramps and watery diarrhoea that may develop into bloody ((haemorrhagic colitis), fever and vomiting.
coli.transmission: Infections are usually caused by the consumption of contaminated food of animal origin such minced meat, undercooked hamburger, raw unpasteurised milk and raw milk cheeses but also leafy green vegetables, sprouts and contaminated drinking water.

yersinia.name: Yersinia
yersinia.description: Y. enterocolitica which can be isolated from many species of mammals and birds is an important cause of gastroenteritis in humans. In contrast to the frequent occurrence of bacteria in pigs, pathogenic Y. enterocolitica have only exceptionally been found on retail pork products.
yersinia.symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, mild fever, vomiting.
yersinia.transmission: Consumption of pork products (tongue, tonsils, gut), cured or uncured, as well as milk and milk products.

brucella.name: Brucella
brucella.description: One of the most widespread zoonoses, brucellosis is caused by various bacteria in the genus Brucella. In humans, the main symptom is recurrent bouts of high temperature, but flu-like symptoms and chronic debilitating disease are also common.
brucella.symptoms: Continuous, intermittent or irregular fever, lassitude, sweat, headache, chills, constipation, arthralgias, generalized aching, weight loss, anorexia.
brucella.transmission: Consumption of milk (usually goat’s or sheep’s milk) and products made from unpasteurized milk (e.g. fresh goat’s cheese).

bacillus-cereus.name: Toxins of Bacillus cereus

cover.alt: Illusttration for Toxins of Bacillus cereus

bacillus-cereus.incubation: Diarrhoeal syndrome: 8 16 hours. Emetic syndrome: 1-5 hours
bacillus-cereus.description: B. cereus can produce two different types of toxins responsible for foodborne illness. The emetic toxin causes vomiting, while the enterotoxin(s) induces diarrhoea. Generally, the disease is self-limiting in 24 hours but occasionally can persist for up to several days. B. cereus spores are ubiquitous in the environment, raw materials, and foods. Improper food handler and storage are the primary reason for toxinogenesis.
bacillus-cereus.symptoms: Diarrhoeal syndrome: acute diarrhoea, nausea and abdominal pain. Emetic syndrome: acute nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain and sometimes diarrhoea.
bacillus-cereus.transmission: Ingestion of food that has been stored at ambient temperatures after cooking, permitting the growth of bacterial spores and toxin production. The most common foods implicated in the emetic syndrome are fried and cooked rice, pasta, pastry, and noodles. Those mainly involved in the diarrheal manifestation are meat products, soups, vegetables, sauces, milk, and milk products.

clostridium-botulinum.name: Clostridium botulinum

cover.alt: Illusttration for Toxins of Bacillus cereus

clostridium-botulinum.description: Botulinum toxins (BoNTs) are the most potent protein poisons known for humans and warm-blooded animals. Since C. botulinum and other BoNT-producing clostridia are environmental microorganisms, they may contaminate raw material and foods. Improper canning or processing can allow spores germination, overgrowth, and toxin production. The consumption of a small amount of foods contaminated with BoNTs can cause a severe neuro-paralytic disease named botulism.
clostridium-botulinum.symptoms: Vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, muscle weakness, headache, constipation, dry mouth and difficulty in swallowing and speaking, and ultimately paralysis and respiratory or heart failure.
clostridium-botulinum.transmission: Ingestion of toxin pre-formed in food. Home-canned vegetables, fermented fish products, canned meat, foods packaged in air-tight or modified-atmosphere containers stored at inappropriate refrigeration conditions are the typical foods associated with foodborne botulism.

clostridium-perfringens.name: Clostridium perfringens

cover.alt: Illusttration for Toxins of Bacillus cereus

clostridium-perfringens.description: Strains of C. perfringens may produce more than 20 toxins and dangerous enzymes. Those responsible for foodborne illness cause mainly stomach cramps and diarrhoea; nausea and vomiting are rare. C. perfringens is widely distributed in the environment including soil, water, species, intestinal tract.
clostridium-perfringens.symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, rarely vomiting and fever.
clostridium-perfringens.transmission: Undercooked, improperly stored (at abusive temperatures), meat dishes are the food items mainly involved in outbreaks. Considering that this microorganism can rapidly multiply, foods slowly cooled after cooking can be at risk. Foods involved include meat and poultry.

staphylococcus-aureus.name: Staphylococcus aureus

cover.alt: Illusttration for Toxins of Bacillus cereus

staphylococcus-aureus.description: S. aureus produces several enterotoxins capable of inducing intoxication. Improperly handling and storage (at abusive temperature) are the leading cause of proliferation and toxinogenesis of S. aureus in foods.
staphylococcus-aureus.symptoms: Severe nausea, abdominal cramps, vomiting sometimes accompanied by diarrhoea, sweating, headache and prostration.
staphylococcus-aureus.transmission: Foods mainly implicated in outbreaks are meat dishes (especially pork and poultry), egg products, salads, bakery products such as cream-filled pastries, sandwich fillings, and milk and dairy products.

norovirus.name: Norovirus (NoV)
norovirus.description: NoV is the most common viral agent causing FBOs worldwide. It is probably a widespread infection in the community, but explosive outbreaks can occur if an infected individual contaminates a common food or water source.
norovirus.symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, watery non-bloody diarrhoea, dehydration.
norovirus.transmission: Contaminated bivalve molluscs consumed raw or undercooked and complex foods are important sources of NoV.

hepatitis-A.name: Hepatitis A virus (HAV)
hepatitis-A.description: HAV infection is almost exclusively via contact with an infected persons or via faecally contaminated food or drink.
hepatitis-A.symptoms: Symptoms of hepatitis A can last up to 2 months and include fatigue, nausea, stomach pain, and jaundice.
hepatitis-A.transmission: Foods involved include shellfish, raw fruit and vegetables, bakery products.

hepatitis-E.name: Hepatitis E virus (HEV)
hepatitis-E.description: HEV usually causes a self-limiting disease but occasionally a serious liver disease in humans can occur.
hepatitis-E.transmission: Main route of transmission is the fecal-oral route via contaminated water. In industrialized countries, other risk factors include eating raw or undercooked pork or wild boar meat.

trichinella.name: Trichinella
trichinella.description: Ten species and three genotypes are currently recognised within the genus Trichinella.
trichinella.symptoms: During the initial larvae invasion symptoms are nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and fever.
trichinella.transmission: Trichinellosis can occur where humans eat raw or undercooked meat products from mammals, birds and reptiles harbouring the infective larvae of the parasite.

toxoplasma.name: Toxoplasma
toxoplasma.description: T. gondii is potentially infective to all vertebrate species, with felids being the definitive host.
toxoplasma.symptoms: Infections often asymptomatic or present as acute disease with lymphadenopathy and lymphocytosis persisting for days or weeks.
toxoplasma.transmission: Ingestion of T. gondii tissue cysts in raw or undercooked meat, of T. gondii tachyzoites in raw milk, and T. gondii sporulated oocysts contaminating fresh produce, shellfish, and water are all risk factors for human infection and were associated to several outbreaks of toxoplasmosis.

cryptosporidium.name: Cryptosporidium
cryptosporidium.description: C. parvum is the most important zoonotic species and it has been demonstrated to be responsible for sporadic outbreaks of water-borne disease.
cryptosporidium.symptoms: Persistent diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain, sometimes accompanied by an influenza-like illness with fever.
cryptosporidium.transmission: Spread through the faecal–oral route, person-to-person contact or consumption of fecally contaminated food and water. Sewage waste and agricultural and urban run-off have been recognised as sources of water contamination.

giardia.name: Giardia
giardia.description: Giardia is an intestinal protozoan infecting humans.
giardia.symptoms: Infection may result in a large range of clinical symptoms, the most common being diarrhoea.
giardia.transmission: Foodborne transmission may occur when food is handled by infected individuals.

histamine.name: Histamine
histamine.description: Histamine is a biogenic amine that is formed in foods by certain bacteria that are able to decarboxylate the amino acid, histidine.
histamine.symptoms: The ingestion of histamine-rich food may cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, red rash, and hypotension.
histamine.transmission: Histamine poisoning results from the consumption of foods, typically certain types of fish and cheeses, that contain unusually high levels of histamine.

marine-biotoxins.name: Marine biotoxins
marine-biotoxins.incubation: Minutes to hours. Less than 12 hours
marine-biotoxins.description: Marine biotoxins are naturally occurring chemicals caused by certain types of toxic algae. Marine biotoxins can accumulate in seafood, and most human illnesses from marine biotoxins occur when people eat contaminated fish or shellfish.
marine-biotoxins.symptoms: Symptoms of Ciguatera fish poisoning can include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach pain. Some people experience tooth pain and a metallic taste in the mouth.
marine-biotoxins.transmission: The most common reported illness caused by marine biotoxin in food is caused by eating fish with high amounts of Ciguatoxins.
